[1] King, M.L. (1958) — Stride Toward Freedom: The Montgomery Story
Relevance Score: 0.91
Source: Internet Archive (1958)
Content: The bus company, which depended heavily on Negro patronage, was suffering financially. At one point it publicly acknowledged that it had lost over 65 percent of its normal revenue during the boycott period.
URL: https://archive.org/details/stridetowardfree00king

[2] Montgomery Advertiser (1956) — Bus Line Financial Reports
Relevance Score: 0.87
Source: Montgomery Advertiser (1956)
Content: City officials reported that the bus line operated at a significant deficit throughout 1956. Ridership dropped from an average of 30,000 daily passengers to fewer than 8,000. The Negro community, which made up approximately 75% of bus riders before the boycott, organized carpools and alternative transportation.
URL: https://newspapers.com/montgomery-advertiser-1956

[1] Little Rock Nine — National Park Service
Relevance Score: 0.94
Source: National Park Service (1957)
Content: The Little Rock Nine were nine African American students who integrated Central High School in Little Rock, Arkansas, in 1957, following the Brown v. Board decision. They were Minnijean Brown, Elizabeth Eckford, Ernest Green, Thelma Mothershed, Melba Pattillo, Gloria Ray, Terrence Roberts, Jefferson Thomas, and Carlotta Walls. They faced violent mobs, death threats, and daily harassment. Governor Orval Faubus called in the Arkansas National Guard to prevent their entry, forcing President Eisenhower to federalize the Guard and send the 101st Airborne Division to escort them to school.
URL: https://www.nps.gov/chsc/learn/historyculture/the-little-rock-nine.htm

Relevance Score: 0.96
Source: NASA (2015)
Content: Katherine Johnson was a NASA mathematician whose calculations were critical to the success of U.S. space missions.
